S. O. Rice has given a prior description of the Q function as defined here [6]. The function is one of the incomplete Toronto functions and has been called the noncentral chi-squared distribution.
Also, no account is given of the effect of "human factors." The probabilities here computed are applicable to the case of an optimal mechanization of the observation process.

The absolute size of the angular errors is atypically small for most cases of interest. This is a consequence of the very small false alarm rates chosen which, in turn, require larger SNR's for detection than usual, by perhaps 3 db. These low false alarm rates do, however, put the quantized case in a poorer light, relative to the analog, than would the more "normal" false alarm rates.

SOSTOOLS is developed as a consequence of the recent interest in SOS polynomials, partly due to the fact that these techniques provide convex relaxations for many hard problems such as global, constrained, and Boolean optimization. for more details, see the manual of SOSTOOLS [34].

A decentralized sliding mode adaptive controller design based on fuzzy neural networks for interconnected uncertain nonlinear systems is introduced in [29].
There are many different aspects between [29] and this approach.
First, the approach in [29] is parameter–free (or model–free) and this approach is based on the T–S fuzzy model.

Comparing with [29], complex learning rules are used in the adaptive fuzzy neural network control to compensate for the effect of the variations on parameters or plant uncertainties, and the proposed \$H_{\infty }\$–decentralized fuzzy controller and fuzzy observer are much simpler and easier to implement than the adaptive controller. \$\hfill{\blacksquare}\$.

context.text: To deal with these problems, some bounded state feedback and output feedback controllers have been developed for linear systems [10]–[16]. in many cases, to avoid the input saturation, low-gain control laws are designed for a prescribed control constraint and known initial system states.

These explicit conditions can be formulated as linear matrix inequalities (LMIs), and thus, it is very easy to obtain the controller gains by solving these LMIs. in fact, this LMI-based anti-windup design can also deal with the tougher actuator rate constraint problem conveniently [16].

Motivated by the recent result [16], the design of this anti-windup dynamic compensator is based on piecewise quadratic Lyapunov functions and can be accomplished by a convex optimization procedure subject to several LMI conditions.

Alternatively, if a common Lyapunov function (CLF) is used in the design of fuzzy anti-windup dynamic compensator like that for linear systems in [16], \$P_{s}\;\hbox{and}\;P_{t}\$ in the conditions (29)–(31) would be replaced by one positive definite matrix \$X\$, and \$V_{s}\;\hbox{and}\;V_{t}\$ by one positive definite block \$Y\$, and all the matrices \$U_{s},U_{t},\;\hbox{and}\;W\$ by \$I_{n+m}\$; moreover, the decision variables \$P_{s},U_{s},\;\hbox{and}\;V_{s}\$ would also be eliminated in the theorem. in fact, the CLF is just one special case of the piecewise Lyapunov function [27], [28]; thus, PLF provides much more freedom of controller design than CLF. and the resulting PLF-based anti-windup controller in Theorem 1 is expected to be less conservative.

context.text: It has been demonstrated that piecewise quadratic Lyapunov functions [27], [28] can be used to reduce the conservatism in the fuzzy stabilizing controller design [25], [26].

Similar to [27] and [28], the output space can be partitioned into a number of closed polyhedral regions, denoted as \$\{{\cal S}_{s}\}_{s\in {\cal I}}\subseteq \Re^{p}\$, where \${\cal I}\$ is the index set of regions. for subsequent use, a set \$\Omega\$ that represents all possible transitions from one region to any possible region including itself is defined as  define a piecewise Lyapunov function candidate for the region \$s\$ by  then, we have  if the Lyapunov function (5) satisfies that \$\Delta V(k)< 0\$ for all trajectories of the system, the system can be guaranteed to be stable in the sense of Lyapunov.

Alternatively, if a common Lyapunov function (CLF) is used in the design of fuzzy anti-windup dynamic compensator like that for linear systems in [16], \$P_{s}\;\hbox{and}\;P_{t}\$ in the conditions (29)–(31) would be replaced by one positive definite matrix \$X\$, and \$V_{s}\;\hbox{and}\;V_{t}\$ by one positive definite block \$Y\$, and all the matrices \$U_{s},U_{t},\;\hbox{and}\;W\$ by \$I_{n+m}\$; moreover, the decision variables \$P_{s},U_{s},\;\hbox{and}\;V_{s}\$ would also be eliminated in the theorem. in fact, the CLF is just one special case of the piecewise Lyapunov function [27], [28]; thus, PLF provides much more freedom of controller design than CLF. and the resulting PLF-based anti-windup controller in Theorem 1 is expected to be less conservative.

context.text: It has been demonstrated that piecewise quadratic Lyapunov functions [27], [28] can be used to reduce the conservatism in the fuzzy stabilizing controller design [25], [26].

Similar to [27] and [28], the output space can be partitioned into a number of closed polyhedral regions, denoted as \$\{{\cal S}_{s}\}_{s\in {\cal I}}\subseteq \Re^{p}\$, where \${\cal I}\$ is the index set of regions. for subsequent use, a set \$\Omega\$ that represents all possible transitions from one region to any possible region including itself is defined as  define a piecewise Lyapunov function candidate for the region \$s\$ by  then, we have  if the Lyapunov function (5) satisfies that \$\Delta V(k)< 0\$ for all trajectories of the system, the system can be guaranteed to be stable in the sense of Lyapunov.

The autonomous piecewise linear system \$x(k+1)=A_{s}x(k)\$ is globally exponentially stable if the following LMIs admit a set of positive definite matrix solutions \$P_{s}\$: Notice that the piecewise quadratic Lyapunov functions [28] are used here to reduce the conservatism in the stabilization problem of a piecewise linear system, which is quite different from the case for a linear time-invariant system.

Alternatively, if a common Lyapunov function (CLF) is used in the design of fuzzy anti-windup dynamic compensator like that for linear systems in [16], \$P_{s}\;\hbox{and}\;P_{t}\$ in the conditions (29)–(31) would be replaced by one positive definite matrix \$X\$, and \$V_{s}\;\hbox{and}\;V_{t}\$ by one positive definite block \$Y\$, and all the matrices \$U_{s},U_{t},\;\hbox{and}\;W\$ by \$I_{n+m}\$; moreover, the decision variables \$P_{s},U_{s},\;\hbox{and}\;V_{s}\$ would also be eliminated in the theorem. in fact, the CLF is just one special case of the piecewise Lyapunov function [27], [28]; thus, PLF provides much more freedom of controller design than CLF. and the resulting PLF-based anti-windup controller in Theorem 1 is expected to be less conservative.

Though KM algorithms have been proven to converge monotonically and superexponentially fast [5], several (usually two to six) iterations are still needed before convergence occurs.

Mendel and Liu also proposed an open problem in [5], i.e., how “to find an optimal way to initialize the KM algorithm,” optimal in the sense that the superexponential convergence factor \$\delta\$ defined in (42) is minimized.

Because \$\delta\$ in [5] is defined for the continuous version of KM algorithms, and in this study, we used the discrete version of KM algorithms, we used the following discrete version of \$\delta\$:  where \$y_{l0}\$ is the initial value of \$y_l\$ [i.e., \$y\$ computed by (16) for the original KM algorithm, or \$y\$ computed by (30) for the EKM algorithm], and \$y_{l1}\$ is \$y'\$ computed from the first iteration of each algorithm.

These definitions are consistent with those used in [5]. for each \$N\$, the 10 000 numbers of iterations from the 10 000 Monte Carlo simulations were recorded for both the original and EKM algorithms, and their mean and standard deviation were computed accordingly, as shown in Fig. 3.
This coincides with the conclusion that the KM algorithms converge monotonically and superexponentially fast [5].

context.text: NWAs are weighted averages in which at least one of the weights are novel models [6], i.e., intervals, type-1 FSs, or IT2 FSs.

In computing the interval weighted average (IWA) [6], \$X_i\$'s are input signals, and \$W_i\$'s are their associated weights, both of which are interval sets. \$Y\$, which is also an interval set, is the IWA.

In computing the fuzzy weighted average (FWA) [4] [6], \$X_i\$'s and \$W_i\$'s are \$\alpha\$-cuts on the input signals and the weights, both of which are type-1 FSs. \$Y\$ is the corresponding \$\alpha\$-cut on the FWA.

In computing the linguistic weighted average (LWA) [12] [6], \$X_i\$ and \$W_i\$ are \$\alpha\$-cuts of the upper membership functions (UMFs) [lower membership functions (LMFs)] of the inputs signals and the weights, both of which are IT2 FSs. \$Y\$ is the corresponding \$\alpha\$-cut on the UMF (LMF) of the LWA, which is also an IT2 FS.

context.text: In computing the centroid of an IT2 FS \$\tilde{A}\$ [2] [5] [8], \$\underline{x}_i=\overline{x}_i=z_i\$ (see Fig. 1) represent discretizations of the primary variable \$z\$, and interval \$[\underline{w}_i,\overline{w}_i]\$ is the membership grade11The lower and upper memberships of \$z_i\$ are usually denoted as \$\underline{\mu}(z_i)\$ and \$\overline{\mu}(z_i)\$, respectively [8].
The lower and upper memberships of \$z_i\$ are usually denoted as \$\underline{\mu}(z_i)\$ and \$\overline{\mu}(z_i)\$, respectively [8].

In centroid and center-of-sums type-reduction of IT2 fuzzy logic systems (FLSs) [8], an IT2 FS is first obtained by combining the output sets for fired rules, after which, computing the type-reduced set is equivalent to computing the centroid of that IT2 FS, as in item a) of 1). \$Y\$ is the type-reduced set.

In center-of-sets type-reduction of IT2 FLSs [8], \$X_i\$ represents the centroid of the consequent IT2 FS of the \$i\$th rule, and \$W_i\$ is the firing level of that rule. \$Y\$ is the type-reduced set.

In height type-reduction of IT2 FLSs [8], \$\underline{x}_i= \overline{x}_i\$ represents the point having maximum membership in the consequent type-1 FS of the \$i\$th rule, and \$W_i\$ is the firing level of that rule. \$Y\$ is the type-reduced set.
The operations in modified height type-reduction [8] are quite similar, except that \$W_i\$ is multiplied by a scale factor.
It is well known that \$y_l\$ and \$y_r\$ in (6) and (7) can be expressed as [8] (the derivation is given in Appendix A)  where \$L\$ and \$R\$ are the switch points satisfying .
Karnik-Mendel (KM) algorithms [2] [8] are used to compute them iteratively.
The shapes of the FOUs are known ahead of time, e.g., in the center-of-sets type-reduction [8], it is necessary to compute the centroids of the consequent IT2 FSs for all rules.

context.text: The standard median filter [1] [2] attempts to remove impulse noise by changing the center pixel of the filtering window with the median of the pixels within the window.

For comparison, the corrupted experimental images are also restored by using a number of conventional as well as state-of-the-art impulse noise removal operators from the literature including the standard median filter (MF) [1], the switching MF (SMF) [6], the tristate MF (TSMF) [10], the signal-dependent rank-ordered MF (SDROMF) [27], the fuzzy filter (FF) [37], the progressive switching MF (PSMF) [7], the multistate MF (MSMF) [12], the edge detecting MF (EDMF) [15], the adaptive fuzzy switching filter (AFSF) [52], the alpha-trimmed mean-based filter (ATMBF) [34], and the adaptive MF with difference type noise detector (DNDAM) [20].

context.text: The weighted median filter and the center-weighted median filter (CWMF) [3]–[4][5], which are modified median filters giving more weight to certain pixels in the filtering window, have been proposed to avoid the inherent drawbacks of the standard median filter.

In addition, the majority of these methods [4]–[12] rely on one or more external parameters (such as a noise density estimate, pixel weighting factors, detection thresholds, etc.) that are heuristically determined by the user.

context.text: A number of methods [6]–[25] combine the median filter with an impulse detector that aims to determine whether the center pixel of a given filtering window is corrupted or not.

As a consequence, several different impulse detection approaches exploiting median filters [6]–[9], CWMSs [10]–[13], Boolean filters [14], edge detection kernels [15], homogeneity level information [16], statistical tests [17] [18], classifier-based methods [19], rule-based methods [20], level detection methods [21], pixel counting methods [22], and soft computing methods [23]–[25] have been proposed.

In addition, the majority of these methods [4]–[6][12] rely on one or more external parameters (such as a noise density estimate, pixel weighting factors, detection thresholds, etc.) that are heuristically determined by the user.

For comparison, the corrupted experimental images are also restored by using a number of conventional as well as state-of-the-art impulse noise removal operators from the literature including the standard median filter (MF) [1], the switching MF (SMF) [6], the tristate MF (TSMF) [10], the signal-dependent rank-ordered MF (SDROMF) [27], the fuzzy filter (FF) [37], the progressive switching MF (PSMF) [7], the multistate MF (MSMF) [12], the edge detecting MF (EDMF) [15], the adaptive fuzzy switching filter (AFSF) [52], the alpha-trimmed mean-based filter (ATMBF) [34], and the adaptive MF with difference type noise detector (DNDAM) [20].

context.text: Numerous PWM methods, aimed at sinusoidal output voltage generation with multiphase inverters, have been developed in recent times [3]–[5][10].

It has been shown that, for a five-phase VSI, both carrier-based methods with the zero-sequence injection and the space vector PWM method allow an increase of 5.15% in the dc-bus utilization, when compared to the simplest sinusoidal modulation without any zero-sequence signal injection [6], [10]. in case of a seven-phase VSI, an increase of 2.57% in the dc-bus utilization is achievable, again with both carrier-based and space vector PWM [5], [7].

context.text: Numerous PWM methods, aimed at sinusoidal output voltage generation with multiphase inverters, have been developed in recent times [3]–[10].

It has been shown that, for a five-phase VSI, both carrier-based methods with the zero-sequence injection and the space vector PWM method allow an increase of 5.15% in the dc-bus utilization, when compared to the simplest sinusoidal modulation without any zero-sequence signal injection [6], [10]. in case of a seven-phase VSI, an increase of 2.57% in the dc-bus utilization is achievable, again with both carrier-based and space vector PWM [5], [7].
Thus, by equating (5) to the value of the dc-bus voltage, one finds that the maximum value of the modulation index in a five-phase system is the value already established in [6] and [10].

The values of the maximum modulation index in the limit of the linear modulation region, established here and already known in literature [5]–[7], [10], are valid as long as the inverters are required to operate with sinusoidal output voltage (i.e., reference voltages are zero in all the planes other than \$d_1 - q_1\$).
As shown in [10], the maximum modulation index is related to the phase number \$n\$ through \$M_{\max } = 1/\cos (\pi /2n)\$.

The CC induction machine model is often transformed into the qd arbitrary reference frame [9], where the flux linkages become decoupled. for convenient derivation of the VBR models, the qd model is included here in decoupled form. in particular, the voltage equations in the ARF are given as .

Since in the VBR model formulation, there is no direct need to calculate the stator flux linkages \$\lambda _{qs}\$ and \$\lambda _{ds}\$, the developed electromagnetic torque may be expressed using the magnetizing fluxes as [9] .

Regardless of the approach, one should bear in mind that the eigenvalues of the induction machine model change quite significantly with speed [9, Ch. 8]. for comparison, the eigenvalues of all models were computed at an operating point close to steady state at no load (operating point corresponding to \$t = \hbox{0.6 s}\$ in the study shown in Fig. 4).

In the state-variable languages, such as the widely used packages SimPowerSystem (SPS) [21] and Piece-wise Linear Electrical Circuit Simulation (PLECS) [22], the qd models are typically represented as voltage-controlled current sources [22], [23].

Therefore, such built-in qd models may not be directly interfaced with external circuits terminating with inductive branches, in which case, fictitious snubbers are often used to create the necessary voltages and enable the interface [21]–[24].

Discretizing the machine models separately from the main system-circuit is possible to avoid algebraic loops. for example, [21] permits discretizing the machine models using the Forward Euler method, while the external circuit may be discretized using a fixed-step trapezoidal (Tustin) integration rule.
Therefore, the direct connection of machine terminals with inductive braches (or current sources) is not possible as it creates difficulties for forming the system’s state space equations [21]–[24].

In the state-variable languages, such as the widely used packages SimPowerSystem (SPS) [21] and Piece-wise Linear Electrical Circuit Simulation (PLECS) [22], the qd models are typically represented as voltage-controlled current sources [22], [23].

Therefore, such built-in qd models may not be directly interfaced with external circuits terminating with inductive branches, in which case, fictitious snubbers are often used to create the necessary voltages and enable the interface [21]–[22][24].

Therefore, the direct connection of machine terminals with inductive braches (or current sources) is not possible as it creates difficulties for forming the system’s state space equations [21]–[22][24].

An approach that is often considered and suggested to the users for interfacing the machine models [22], [23] is to use an artificial shunt snubber circuit (very large resistors and/or small capacitors), which makes it possible to calculate the voltages at the interconnection point of the machine model and the external circuit, and therefore, completes the interface. in the studies presented here, to enable the SPS model interface, a shunt resistive branch was connected, as shown in Fig. 10. in general, the values of such artificial snubbers are chosen large enough as to minimize their effect on the simulation accuracy.

context.text: A voltage-behind-reactance (VBR) model formulation was proposed for synchronous machines in [31] and [32] that also achieves the direct interface sought by the CC phase-domain model.

The VBR models and the CC model were implemented using the circuit-based approach described in [35] and the toolbox [36]. in general, similar to a synchronous machine ([31], see Section V), the CC model could be implemented using either currents or the flux linkages as the state variables.

To gain some qualitative information and understanding of the numerical properties of the machine models described here, one may consider the state equations formed by the electrical circuit (see Fig. 2) of the machine [31]. in particular, if the rotor speed is assumed to be constant, the machine’s nonlinear equations become linear, which allows one to express the corresponding system matrices.
A similar observation regarding the synchronous machine models has been made in [31].

context.text: It has been reported that due to the unbalanced input supply voltages and impedances, there exist odd harmonics in ac input currents and fluctuations in the dc-link voltage [4].

To compensate for the unbalanced input supply, it is vitally important that the current regulators control both the positive- and negative-sequence components accurately. in the previous studies [4]–[9], the negative-sequence current was independently regulated, which necessitates the use of sequential-component decomposing filters that might narrow the controller bandwidth and overall stability margin.

Unlike the traditionally dual current regulators, in which there exist dc signals in the positive and negative synchronously rotating reference frames [4]–[9], the proposed current regulators, shown in Fig. 4, have ac values with multifrequency components. in order to eliminate the regulating errors for multiple harmonic currents, such as the third and the fifth components, a PR regulator in the stationary \$\alpha\beta\$ frame is introduced and expanded as a multifrequency proportional-resonant (MFPR) one, as depicted in Fig. 5.

references.text: P. Rioual, H. Pouliquen and J. Louis, "Regulation of a PWM rectifier in the unbalanced network state using a generalized model", IEEE Trans. Power Electron., vol. 11, no. 3, pp. 495-502, May 1996.
references.title:
Regulation of a PWM rectifier in the
 unbalanced network state using a generalized model

context.text: It was concluded that the control schemes, which are adopted to regulate the instantaneous active power at the input of VSC in dq synchronous frame for eliminating the harmonics of the controlled PWM rectifier under the unbalanced input supply voltage [5]–[7], have their inherent defects including: 1) unregulated instantaneous reactive power, resulting from the conventionally balanced reactive power definition applied, which is certainly inapplicable under extreme generalized unbalanced input supply due to the ignoring of the instantaneous power exchanged with the VSC interface inductors and 2) low bandwidth of current regulators caused by the positive- and negative-sequence dq component decomposing schemes.

To compensate for the unbalanced input supply, it is vitally important that the current regulators control both the positive- and negative-sequence components accurately. in the previous studies [4]–[5][9], the negative-sequence current was independently regulated, which necessitates the use of sequential-component decomposing filters that might narrow the controller bandwidth and overall stability margin.

Unlike the traditionally dual current regulators, in which there exist dc signals in the positive and negative synchronously rotating reference frames [4]–[5][9], the proposed current regulators, shown in Fig. 4, have ac values with multifrequency components. in order to eliminate the regulating errors for multiple harmonic currents, such as the third and the fifth components, a PR regulator in the stationary \$\alpha\beta\$ frame is introduced and expanded as a multifrequency proportional-resonant (MFPR) one, as depicted in Fig. 5.

context.text: It was concluded that the control schemes, which are adopted to regulate the instantaneous active power at the input of VSC in dq synchronous frame for eliminating the harmonics of the controlled PWM rectifier under the unbalanced input supply voltage [5]–[6][7], have their inherent defects including: 1) unregulated instantaneous reactive power, resulting from the conventionally balanced reactive power definition applied, which is certainly inapplicable under extreme generalized unbalanced input supply due to the ignoring of the instantaneous power exchanged with the VSC interface inductors and 2) low bandwidth of current regulators caused by the positive- and negative-sequence dq component decomposing schemes.

To compensate for the unbalanced input supply, it is vitally important that the current regulators control both the positive- and negative-sequence components accurately. in the previous studies [4]–[6][9], the negative-sequence current was independently regulated, which necessitates the use of sequential-component decomposing filters that might narrow the controller bandwidth and overall stability margin.

Unlike the traditionally dual current regulators, in which there exist dc signals in the positive and negative synchronously rotating reference frames [4]–[6][9], the proposed current regulators, shown in Fig. 4, have ac values with multifrequency components. in order to eliminate the regulating errors for multiple harmonic currents, such as the third and the fifth components, a PR regulator in the stationary \$\alpha\beta\$ frame is introduced and expanded as a multifrequency proportional-resonant (MFPR) one, as depicted in Fig. 5.

A tenfold cross validation was used in all the algorithms except [42] and the proposed algorithms.
The data sets were partitioned into training and testing sets in [42], whereas they were partitioned into training, validation, and testing sets in this paper.
For one problem, the bagged NN tested in [42] achieved the smallest error rate, whereas NegBagg achieved the third smallest error rate.
The reason that NegBagg was outperformed by CNNE and bagged NN [42] on two and one problems, respectively, might be its nonoptimal setting of \$M\$, i.e., the number of NNs in the ensemble.
In [42], a large ensemble architecture was used for the letter problem, which might be suitable for this problem.
Furthermore, the training strategies used in CNNE, bagged NN [42], and NegBagg were different, and they might contribute to the performance difference.

It is observed in Tables VI and VII that the error rate of NegBagg and NegBoost was worse than that of bagging and boosting tested in [42] for the letter problem, which was the largest problem among all the problems considered in this paper.
M2 was used in [42], which is superior to the boosting algorithm used in NegBoost.
Furthermore, the ensemble architecture used in [42] for the letter problem was much larger than that automatically obtained by NegBagg and NegBoost.

Since the pulse is propagating in the soil and there exists an air–soil interface, the important parameters that influence the pulse propagation from the perspective of a TL analysis will be the ground return parameters, viz., the ground impedance and the admittance terms [4]–[5][6], [20], [21].

Based on the per unit length impedance and admittance parameters, the representation of differential length TL model for the bare wire is shown in Fig. 1(a) and that of the insulated wire is shown in Fig. 1(b) [5], [6], [13], [20], [21].
The internal impedance [5], [6] is neglected in our analysis owing to its negligible contribution compared to the ground impedance [22] to the overall self-series impedance of the line.

The per unit length inductance and capacitance due to the insulation thickness are calculated using the following [6], [20], [21]: The ground impedance for a wire with outermost radius \$R\$ with the ground propagation constant \$\gamma _g = \sqrt {j\omega \mu _0 \sigma _g - \omega ^2 \mu _0 \varepsilon _g }\$ is given by (4) taken from Theethayi et al. [13] The ground admittance can be obtained from the ground impedance as [5], [6] .
That is why researchers like Vance [5] ignored the wire depth in the expressions for the ground impedance.

Note that in expression (4), if the contribution from the depth is ignored, we obtain the expression for the ground impedance proposed by Petrache et al. [2], which is also similar to the corresponding expression proposed by Vance [5] in terms of Hankel functions as discussed by Theethayi et al. [13].
It should be noted that the discussion here is applicable to an infinite earth model [5].
The penetration depth in the soil can be calculated using the following expression [5]: .

Further, the maximum velocity of the waves propagating in the soil is determined by its permittivity [5], i.e., \${\hbox{lim}}_{\omega \to \infty } \upsilon _g \to c/\sqrt {\varepsilon _{rg} } = \upsilon _{g\max }\$.

context.text: Unlike overhead wires for which the limits of the TL approximation have fairly been studied in the literature, e.g., [4]–[6][12], there has been no such study for buried wires.

Since the pulse is propagating in the soil and there exists an air–soil interface, the important parameters that influence the pulse propagation from the perspective of a TL analysis will be the ground return parameters, viz., the ground impedance and the admittance terms [4]–[6], [20], [21].

Based on the per unit length impedance and admittance parameters, the representation of differential length TL model for the bare wire is shown in Fig. 1(a) and that of the insulated wire is shown in Fig. 1(b) [5], [6], [13], [20], [21].
The internal impedance [5], [6] is neglected in our analysis owing to its negligible contribution compared to the ground impedance [22] to the overall self-series impedance of the line.
Considering wire as a perfect conductor, the self-shunt admittance of the bare wire is due to the electric fields in the soil and is represented by the ground admittance [6].
More details can be found in [6], [20], and [21].

The per unit length inductance and capacitance due to the insulation thickness are calculated using the following [6], [20], [21]: The ground impedance for a wire with outermost radius \$R\$ with the ground propagation constant \$\gamma _g = \sqrt {j\omega \mu _0 \sigma _g - \omega ^2 \mu _0 \varepsilon _g }\$ is given by (4) taken from Theethayi et al. [13] The ground admittance can be obtained from the ground impedance as [5], [6] .

A clear demarcation on the applicability between the TL equations and full-wave Maxwell's equations can be envisaged if the comparison of current distribution along the wire is analyzed solely in frequency domain (say using NEC [6], [28]), i.e., comparing for each frequency sweep the current distribution along the wire.

Further, the injected source currents are typical double-exponential waveforms, which have a spectrum of frequency, and since in the time domain, they have been averaged out, the TEM mode and antenna modes [6] contributions would be difficult to visualize.
A current wave propagating along the line during its risetimes could have dominance of TEM over other modes of propagation [6].

context.text: The time discretization in either method is decided based on wavelength conditions [17], [35], [36].

Note that an FDTD discretization of the geometry or domain (cell for full-wave Maxwell's equations and elemental length for TL equations) leads to a different number of unknowns depending on the method adopted, i.e., for the TL problem, the unknowns are the voltage and the current; while for the FDTD solution of Maxwell's equations, the unknowns are the six field components [35].

This is because, unlike in the full-wave solution of Maxwell's equations by the FDTD method [35], [36], in the TL method, all the field propagation into the media (air and soil) has been transformed to the corresponding line impedance (magnetic field) and line admittance (electric field)—a problem somewhat similar to the 1-D (Maxwell's equations) wave propagation in the transverse electromagnetic (TEM) mode [35], [36].

context.text: Section 2 provides an overview of the correlated link fading model used in this paper, the network shadowing (NeSh) model, which was reported in [2].
Perhaps the best motivation is that link shadowing correlations have been experimentally observed in measured sensor networks [2], yet their impacts have not yet been studied.
In this paper, we apply the network shadowing (NeSh) model of [2].
The NeSh model was tested in a measurement campaign in [2] which measured fifteen realizations of indoor wireless sensor networks.
In [2], these are reported to be \$\sigma_{X}^{2}/\sigma_{dB}^{2}=0.29\$ and \$\delta=0.21{\rm m}\$.
Second, the model in [2] was tested for 2-D, not 3-D deployments.
We have chosen \$\sigma_{dB}=7.0, n_{p}=3.0\$, and \$\Delta_{0}=1{\rm m}\$; and the measured parameters of \$\delta=0.21{\rm m}\$ and \$\sigma_{X}/\sigma_{dB}=0.29\$ from [2].

context.text: Elliptic curve cryptography (ECC) is an approach to publickey cryptography based on the algebraic structure of elliptic curves over finite fields [16].
An elliptic curve over \$F_{p}\$ is defined by a cubic equation \$y^{2}=x^{3}+ax+b\$, where \$a,b\in F_{p}\$ are constants such that \$4a^{3}+27b^{3}\neq 0\$ [16].
The points on an elliptic curve form an abelian group with \$\scr O\$ as the additive identity. (The formulas defining point addition and its special case, point doubling, can be found in [16].).
For any point \$G\$ on an elliptic curve, the set \$\{{\scr O},G,2G,3G, \ldots\}\$ is a cyclic group [16].
It is computationally infeasible to solve ECDLP for appropriate parameters [16].
ECIES is a public-key encryption scheme which provides semantic security against an adversary who is allowed to use chosen-plaintext and chosen-ciphertext attacks [16].
The specification of ECDH, ECDSA, and ECIES can be found in [8], [16].
Using a projective coordinate system [16], modular inversions can be removed with the compensation of a few modular multiplications and squares.
As a result, the execution times of point addition and point doubling based on projective coordinate system are faster than those based on affine coordinate system, respectively [16].
The first is a mixed point addition algorithm [16], which adds a point in projective coordinate and a second point in affine coordinate.
The second is repeated Doubling [16] for scalar multiplication.

In \$m\$ consecutive doublings, this algorithm trades \$m-1\$ field additions, \$m-1\$ divisions by two, and a multiplication for two field squarings (in comparison with repeated applications of the plain point doubling algorithm) [16].
A comprehensive guide for elliptic curve cryptography is given in [16].

references.text: K. Zielinski, P. Weitkemper, R. Laur and K.-D. Kammeyer, "Parameter study for differential evolution using a power allocation problem including interference cancellation", Proc. IEEE Congr. Evol. Comput., pp. 6748-6755, 2006.
references.title: Parameter study for differential evolution using a power allocation problem including interference cancellation

context.text: In previous work, it has already been shown that the power allocation scheme for parallel interference cancellation (PIC) can be successfully optimized by differential evolution (DE) which is an optimization algorithm that belongs to the class of evolutionary algorithms (EAs) [1].

Furthermore, the results of PSO should be compared with the DE approach described in [1], so the implementations of the algorithms are intended to be as similar as possible concerning details like this one.
Therefore, for first examinations the number of individuals is set to \$N\!P=80\$ like in a similar study that included the same optimization problem with a differential evolution algorithm [1].
The best objective function value of the PIC optimization problem is given as \$f(\vec{x}^{\ast})=18.43\$ in [1] (actually, this value was rounded from \$f(\vec{x}^{\ast})=18.4300288\$).

The lbest neighborhood with the parameter settings \$w=0.4\$, \$c_{1}=2.0\$ and \$c_{2}=1.6\$ [with update according to (11)] results in the best objective function value \$f(\vec{x}^{\ast})=18.3935308035483\$ that is better than the best solution found by DE (however, in [1] the number of function evaluations was only \$f\!e_{\rm max}=40\,000\$).

This value is only found once in 300\$\thinspace\$000 optimization runs, thus in the following convergence is defined as reaching an objective function value of \$f(x)\leq 18.5\$ (the same simplification was done for DE in [1]). from the communications point of view the difference to the best value that was found is negligible.
In [1], the optimal value found here was not even met once using DE with \$f\!e_{\rm max}=40\,000\$.
Convergence rates of \$\geq\$90% are reached for \$N\!P\geq 40\$, whereas in [1] \$N\!P=30\$ is sufficient for a convergence rate of 100% using DE.
In the following, the main results concerning convergence probability and convergence speed from the examination shown in [1] will be summarized and compared with the results using PSO.
Unfortunately, different conditions were used in [1] compared with this work: The maximum number of generations was 500 whereas \$G_{\rm max}=1000\$ was used for PSO here.

It can be concluded that depending on parameter settings PSO is able to yield competitive results compared with [1], and surprisingly the variant with (6) (refreshing the random numbers only once for each particle in every generation) is even better than using (11) (recalculating the random numbers for every component of the velocity). with (6) the success cost is almost 20% lower than in [1].
The same increase in users has been found in former work using a differential evolution algorithm [1].

In this work, the velocities are randomly initialized in \$[-V_{\rm max},V_{\rm max}]\$ (as it is also done, e.g., in [9]), where the maximum velocity \$V_{\rm max}\$ is one half of the search space in each dimension: \$V_{{\rm max},j}=(X_{{\rm max},j}-X_{\min,j})/2\$ for \$j\in\{1,\ldots,D\}\$.
For several years nothing has been published about this ambiguity, but in recent years emphasis of this difference begins to appear [9], [29], [30].

While [29] (which is written by one of the two developers of PSO) states that the random numbers should be unique for each dimension but does not give a reason, in [9] it is stated that exploration is restricted because the distribution of possible locations of the particles is limited, and a thorough discussion about this topic can be found in [30].

However, he states that using a different random number for each dimension of every particle also has a disadvantage which is observer dependence, so this PSO variant is rotationally variant (this is also mentioned in [9], where the author states that the distribution of possible locations of the particles depends on the coordinate system).

Another variant that not only adapts the population size but does not need any parameter to be set is the TRIBES algorithm that shows good results in [9], but apart from that not many experiments using it can be found in the literature.

The adaptive approaches may improve the PSO algorithm if the new parameters are more robust than the ones that are substituted but generally adaptive methods should decrease the number of parameters as described in [9].
It is concluded that it is very difficult to derive general guidelines for parameter settings of PSO, so it is important to pursue adaptive approaches, e.g., like described in [9].

context.text: For several years nothing has been published about this ambiguity, but in recent years emphasis of this difference begins to appear [9], [29], [30].

While [29] (which is written by one of the two developers of PSO) states that the random numbers should be unique for each dimension but does not give a reason, in [9] it is stated that exploration is restricted because the distribution of possible locations of the particles is limited, and a thorough discussion about this topic can be found in [30].

The author of [30] conducts an analytical as well as an empirical study and concludes that refreshing the random numbers only once for every particle might result in limitations of the particle trajectories and therefore in a loss of diversity if the personal and neighborhood best positions stay the same for a long time.
Therefore, in [30] a new formulation of the update equations is proposed that includes the use of rotation matrices.

If the personal and neighborhood best positions change frequently, enough diversity might already be present but as stated in [30], there are also several possibilities to generate additional diversity: Using random velocities at initialization (the effect of this may fade over time), employing local neighborhoods, setting a maximum and/or minimum velocity, implementing a position restriction, inserting a craziness operator or increasing the number of particles which contribute to the update equations (social awareness).

Since up to now not much research exists about performance differences, the PSO formulations according to (6) and (11) will be compared in the following (the newly developed variant from [30] is omitted because of its additional parameter that makes comparisons difficult).
In [30], it is mentioned that optimal parameter settings differ for these PSO formulations.

The outcome that the same parameter settings yield the best performance for both ways of refreshing the random numbers contradicts the statement of [30] that optimal settings differ for the PSO variants with (11) or (6).
This can be explained by the loss in diversity that is discussed in [30].

Another interesting result is that the same parameter settings are found to be best for both variants of refreshing the random numbers although in [30] it is stated that different settings will provide best results for these variants.

context.text: Recently, several new approaches are developed to estimate the overall system bit error rate (BER) with deterministic and random jitter effects [1]–[3][7].
The most popular approaches are based on a statistical eye consisting of the ISI probability distributions at different sampling phases [1]–[3][5].
The majority of these techniques assume a white random jitter spectrum, and the clock-data recovery (CDR) phase dither is often ignored [1]–[3], [5].

On the other hand, popular statistical approach such as StatEye ignores the effects of channel and jitter on CDR dither and simply models CDR as part of receiver sampling jitter, resulting in inaccurate predictions of the overall system performance [3].
Assuming random input data patterns and symmetric rising and falling edges [1]–[3][5], [8], the ISI PDF is calculated by convolving ISI components in the SBR.
Previous statistical methodologies [1]–[3][5] have different models for random jitter.

context.text: Recently, several new approaches are developed to estimate the overall system bit error rate (BER) with deterministic and random jitter effects [1]–[4][7].
The most popular approaches are based on a statistical eye consisting of the ISI probability distributions at different sampling phases [1]–[4][5].

The statistical simulation technique described in [4] resolves many of these issues: colored random jitter is modeled using autocorrelation, and CDR is modeled using a Markov chain to include the channel and any jitter effects.
This paper presents accuracy improvements to the method proposed in [4].
Assuming random input data patterns and symmetric rising and falling edges [1]–[4][5], [8], the ISI PDF is calculated by convolving ISI components in the SBR.
Previous statistical methodologies [1]–[4][5] have different models for random jitter.
Most of them, [1]–[3], [5], ignore jitter spectrum while [4] models colored Gaussian random jitter.
This section generalizes the method in [4] to handle bounded jitter with arbitrary spectrum.

On the other hand, when \$\varepsilon _{m}^{RX}\$ is unbounded Gaussian, we can approximate it as a single Gaussian random variable with variance of \$E_{\varepsilon ^{RX} } \vec h_{RX} ^{T} {\bf{W}}^{T} {\bf{W}}\vec h_{RX}\$ where \$E_{\varepsilon ^{RX} }\$ is the receiver jitter variance [4].
Fast algorithms are introduced in [4] and [11] for specific cases.
For example, [4] assumes jitter has a Gaussian distribution, while [11] assumes that transmitter jitter is white and bounded and that transmitted symbols are independent.

context.text: We also discuss how the presented formulation can be solved using Kelley's Cutting Plane algorithm [25].
The presented posynomial formulation is translated into a convex one (exponential form) by the change of variables \$s_{i}=e^{x_{i}}\$ and \$t_{i}=e^{y_{i}}\$ [25].
The previous formulation will consequently have an exponential optimization form, which is convex with respect to \$\vec {x}\$ [25].

To do so, it is sufficient to show that the optimizations' objective is convex because the constraints of this optimization problem can be represented in an exponential form similar to Section III-C and therefore will form a convex set [25].

To show \$v(\vec {x},\vec {\omega })\$ is a convex function by definition, we need to show for \$\vec {x_{1}}\$ and \$\vec {x_{2}}\$, the following inequality holds (for \$0 \leq \theta \leq 1\$) [25]:  where \$v(x_{1},\vec {\omega })\$ and \$v(x_{2},\vec {\omega })\$ are optimal solutions of optimization set expressed by inequalities of (15).

Since it is known that positive-weight integration/summation of convex functions is a convex function [25], to prove the convexity of \$E[]\$, it would be sufficient to prove each individual penalty sample is convex with respect to \$\vec {x}\$.
We used the Kelley's cutting plane technique [25] among other possible methods, which is briefly explained in the following.

This gives us a new value for \$\vec {x}_{k}\$ and the entire process is repeated till the lower bound approximation and the upper bound are within a user specified range of tolerance [note that each \$\vec {x}_{k}\$ corresponds to an upper bound \${\rm BYL}(\vec {x_{k}})\$] [25].
In this paper, we will be using the finite-difference method [25].

Transient response to a \$-\$1000 A perturbation on \$i _{2}\$ and under 15% of nominal grid voltage for the proposed (NLSC) and the reported one in [21] (NLC).

Moreover, these simulations have been also performed for the controlled reported in [21] in order to compare the results with the proposed controller.

The results show that the impact of the mismatch on the peak current levels is less than 1.76% around nominal for the proposed controller and less than 4.47% around nominal for the controller reported in [21].

Although these mismatches were realized among one of the parameters while the others were maintained at the nominal value, simulations in the worst case of mismatch over all these parameters were performed, giving similar results with peak current levels below 2.89% nominal for the proposed controller and below 7.64% nominal for the controller reported in [21].

references.title: Reinforcement Learning: An Introduction

context.text: Reinforcement learning (RL) algorithms [1], [2] are very suitable for learning to control an agent by letting it interact with an environment.

There are a number of different online model-free value-function-based RL algorithms that use the discounted future reward criterion. \$Q\$-learning [3], Sarsa [4], [5], and AC methods [1] are well known, and there are also two more recent algorithms: \$QV\$-learning [6] and AC learning automaton (ACLA) [6].

In order to learn an optimal policy, value-function-based RL [1] estimates value functions by using past experiences of the agent. \$Q^{\pi}(s, a)\$ is defined as the expected cumulative discounted future reward if the agent is in state \$s\$, executes action \$a\$, and follows policy \$\pi\$ afterward where \$0 \leq \gamma \leq 1\$ is the discount factor that values later rewards less compared with immediate rewards.
In contrast to \$Q\$-learning and Sarsa, AC methods keep track of two functions: a critic that evaluates states and an actor that maps states to a preference value for each action [1].

It is known that better convergence guarantees exist for on-policy methods when combined with function approximators [1] because it has been shown that \$Q\$-learning can diverge in this case [21], [22].

context.text: There are a number of different online model-free value-function-based RL algorithms that use the discounted future reward criterion. \$Q\$-learning [3], Sarsa [4], [5], and AC methods [1] are well known, and there are also two more recent algorithms: \$QV\$-learning [6] and AC learning automaton (ACLA) [6].
\$QV\$-learning [6] works by keeping track of both the \$Q\$- and \$V\$-functions.

ACLA [6] learns a state-value function in the same way as AC and \$QV\$-learning, but ACLA uses a learning automatonlike update rule [20] for changing the policy mapping states to probabilities (or preferences) for actions.
ACLA was shown to outperform \$Q\$-learning and Sarsa on a number of problems when \$\epsilon\$-greedy exploration was used [6].

context.text: Therefore, the issues of how to determine the structure and estimate the parameters of an FIS have attracted great attentions in [1]–[7][11].
Several researchers have utilized conventional RL approaches to train the consequent parts of FISs [5], [7]–[9].
The fuzzy \$Q\$-learning (FQL) is proposed in [7], where the consequent parameters of FISs are selected from a fixed action set via RL.
The structure and premise parameters of FISs are predefined in the FQL of [7], which needs great human efforts.
An optimal action set is obtained via a genetic algorithm (GA), and the FQL of [7] is adopted to search for the best consequent parameters in the action set.
In [7] and [9], the antecedent parts of the FIS are regarded as states, and the consequent parts are selected from an action set by competitions among the \$q\$-values.
To explore the set of possible actions and acquire experiences through reinforcement signals, the actions are selected using an exploration–exploitation strategy of Jouffe [7] and Er and Deng [9].
First, the local best matched state–action pattern is selected as that in the FQL [7], and it is considered as a candidate for the global election.

In [9], it has been shown that the dynamic FQL (DFQL) is superior to the basic fuzzy controller, fixed FQL [7], and continuous-action \$Q\$-learning [19], and the author of [8] proved that the CQGAF is superior to the traditional GA.

Since the authors have shown that the CQGAF is superior to the traditional GA, and the DFQL is superior to the basic fuzzy controller, the fixed FQL of Jouffe [7], and the continuous-action \$Q\$-learning of Millan et al. [19] in [8] and [9], comparison studies for those methods are not included here.

In [8], the author proposed an online Clustering and \$Q\$-value-based Genetic Algorithm learning scheme for Fuzzy system design (CQGAF) to search for consequent parameters of each rule without any action sets.
The structure and premise parameters are generated only by a clustering method in [8], which is not sufficient.
Instead of directly searching optimal consequent parameters in [8], a hierarchical learning strategy is proposed in the EDSGFIS.
If the Euclidean distance does not pass the similarity test as mentioned in [8] and [9], there will be no new MF created.
Inspired by the results of Juang [8], \$q\$-values are selected as the fitness for GA evolution.
However, instead of directly applying the GA to search for optimal actions in [8], hierarchical learning is adopted, and different approaches for crossover and mutation are applied in the EDSGFIS.

In [9], it has been shown that the dynamic FQL (DFQL) is superior to the basic fuzzy controller, fixed FQL [7], and continuous-action \$Q\$-learning [19], and the author of [8] proved that the CQGAF is superior to the traditional GA.
Hence, in this paper, it is sufficient for us to compare the EDSGFIS with the CQGAF of [8] and the DFQL of [9].

Since the authors have shown that the CQGAF is superior to the traditional GA, and the DFQL is superior to the basic fuzzy controller, the fixed FQL of Jouffe [7], and the continuous-action \$Q\$-learning of Millan et al. [19] in [8] and [9], comparison studies for those methods are not included here.

To explore the set of possible actions and acquire experiences through reinforcement signals, the actions are selected using an exploration–exploitation strategy of Jouffe [7] and Er and Deng [9].
Similar to the simulation studies in [9], the task is to design a controller for wall following while the robot is only moving in a clockwise direction at a fixed speed.

The same reward function as what is used in [9] is adopted, i.e., .
Here, \$d_{-} = 0.15\$ and \$d_{+} = 0.85\$ are normalized values of sensors, and \$U\$ is the output steering angle, and the same settings as those of [9] are adopted.

In [9], it has been shown that the dynamic FQL (DFQL) is superior to the basic fuzzy controller, fixed FQL [7], and continuous-action \$Q\$-learning [19], and the author of [8] proved that the CQGAF is superior to the traditional GA.
Hence, in this paper, it is sufficient for us to compare the EDSGFIS with the CQGAF of [8] and the DFQL of [9].

For the DFQL, the same setting as in [9] has been adopted, i.e., initial \$q\$-value \$k_{q} = 3.0\$, exploration rate \$S_{p} = 0.001\$, discounted factor \$\gamma = 0.95\$, trace-decay factor \$\lambda = 0.7\$, learning rate \$\alpha = 0.05\$, \$\varepsilon = 0.5\$, similarity of MF, and \$k_{\rm mf} = 0.3\$.

In this section, we briefly review the main properties of Mercer's kernels and the standard formulations for the binary SVC and for the one-class SVDD used in this paper, which have demonstrated excellent characteristics in problems with a low number of high-dimensional training samples [30], [31].
In [30], Camps-Valls et al. also exploited the same methodology to integrate the spatial (contextual or textural) and the spectral information in kernel-based hyperspectral image classifiers.

However, by exploiting the previous composite methods, one can define several contextual kernel classifiers [30]: the direct summation kernel, which is given by \$K({\bf x}_{i}^{(t_{o})}, {\bf x}_{j}^{(t_{o})}) = K_{s}({\mmb s}_{i}^{(t_{o})}, {\mmb s}_{j}^{(t_{o})}) + K_{\omega}({\mmb \omega}_{i}^{(t_{o})},\break {\mmb \omega}_{j}^{(t_{o})})\$, and the cross-information kernel, which is given by \$K({\bf x}_{i}^{(t_{o})}, {\bf x}_{j}^{(t_{o})}) = K_{s}({\mmb s}_{i}^{(t_{o})}, {\mmb s}_{j}^{(t_{o})}) + K_{\omega}({\mmb \omega}_{i}^{(t_{o})}, {\mmb \omega}_{j}^{(t_{o})}) + K_{s\omega}({\mmb s}_{i}^{(t_{o})}, {\mmb \omega}_{j}^{(t_{o})}) + K_{\omega s}({\mmb \omega}_{i}^{(t_{o})}, {\mmb s}_{j}^{(t_{o})})\$.

Considering that the number of potentially useful combinations of (spatial, spectral, temporal, and multisource) composite kernels is very high, in this paper, we will restrict ourselves to present results on those combinations showing the best performance according to our previous experience and experiments [30], [31], [39], [40].

The ensemble of graphs with undirected links connecting all those pairs \$\{{\bf x}_{i}, {\bf x}_{j}\}\$ with \$\Vert {\bf x}_{i}-{\bf x}_{j}\Vert\leq r, r > 0\$, is called a random geometric graph [6], and denoted as \$G({\cal X}_{n}, r)\$.

 In this case, as \$n\rightarrow\infty\$ and \$A\rightarrow\infty\$ with \${n\over A}=\lambda\$ fixed, \$G({\cal X}_{n}, r)\$ converges in distribution to an (infinite) random geometric graph \$G({\cal H}_{\lambda}, r)\$ induced by a homogeneous Poisson point process with density \$\lambda>0\$.
Due to the scaling property of random geometric graphs [5], [6], in the following, we focus on \$G({\cal H}_{\lambda}, 1)\$.

context.text: The key enabling technology is virtual concatenation (VCAT), which make it possible to split data traffic in a finer granularity and hence make use of link capacity more efficiently [1].
With the relatively high frequency of fiber cuts and the tremendous traffic loss a failure may cause, survivability in multipath provisioning is a critical concern [1], [4].

We show that searching for optimal K disjoint paths (referred to as \$O-K\$–paths) is efficient for survivable multipath provisioning, which is similar to the Optimal Path Pair (OPP) [1] in traditional single-path protection.
We only consider single link failure since this is the dominant network failure in practice and the nodes are normally \$1+1\$ protected [1].

context.text: In recent years a number of papers [25], [12], [24], [19] have addressed this issue by considering algorithms for jointly combining congestion control and scheduling.
Our approach is based on the solution from the paper [25] that was called the Greedy Primal-Dual algorithm (GPD).
Then, according to the results of [25], this algorithm provides a control that solves the above optimization problem.
However, there were a number of issues raised by the scheme of [25] that need to be addressed before it can be fully realized as a scheme for the control of mobile ad-hoc networks.
We now describe the theoretical Greedy Primal-Dual algorithm for combined congestion control and scheduling that was introduced in [25] and was shown to solve the above optimization problem.
The main theoretical result of [25] is that as \$\beta\$ approaches zero, the flow rates produced by the GPD algorithm approach the optimal solution of the above optimization problem.
This issue was addressed by a set of recent papers [25], [12], [24], [19] that provide methods for joint congestion control and scheduling with the goal of optimizing aggregate network utility.
The paper [25] introduced the GPD algorithm that is the motivation for the wGPD protocols that we present in this paper.

context.text: The seminal work of Tassiulas and Ephremides [27], [28] analyzed an algorithm (that we shall henceforth refer to as Max-Weight) that always tries to move data from large queues to small queues.

The urgency weight for queue \$Q_{d}^{i}\$ is denoted by \$w_{d}^{i}\$ and is defined by \$w_{d}^{i}=[q_{d}^{i}-q_{d}^{n(i, d)}]r_{i, n(i, d)}\$, i.e. the urgency weight is set to be the difference of the PDQ size at the current node minus the associated PDQ size at the downstream node, multiplied by the channel rate between these nodes. (This urgency weight is essentially the scheduling weight used by the Max-Weight algorithm of Tassiulas-Ephremides [27], [28] and its definition is why scheduling schemes that are based on it are often known as differential backlog scheduling schemes.).

Early work on scheduling includes the well-known papers of Tassiulas and Ephremides [27], [28] who showed that scheduling schemes based on queue sizes can maintain queue stability for inelastic traffic whenever this is feasible. (See also Awerbuch and Leighton [7].) More recent research has looked at scheduling issues in single-hop cellular-type networks.

context.text: Cell selection has received much attention in recent years (e.g., [4] – [7]) where research focused mainly on multiple-access techniques, as well as on power control schemes and handoff protocols [4], [5], [7].

An HSPA-based handoff/cell-site selection technique is presented in [4], [5], where the objective is to maximize the number of connected mobile stations (very similar to our objective), and reaching the optimality of this objective is done via a new scheduling algorithm for this cellular system.
In the case of [4], [5], this enables the authors to reduce their corresponding optimization problem to a polynomial-time solvable matching problem.

context.text: We consider a pricing scheme inspired by the (monopolist) one introduced in [15], where users are charged for the number of packets they submit regardless of their being treated or lost, in order to incentivize them to limit their demand.

Remark that the type of slotted and capacity-based model we are dealing with can be related to the one in [15], where a similar slotted capacity model is used, but with several priority traffic classes, and in the case of a monopoly instead of an oligopoly here.

Indeed, capacity could also be an important parameter providers can play with, at the same time as prices: what would be the resulting equilibrium? context.text: Over the last few years there has been significant interest in studying the scheduling problem for multi–hop wireless networks [1]–[2][9].
While the optimal solution of this scheduling problem has been known for a long time [2], the resultant solution has high computational complexity and is difficult to implement in multi–hop networks.

For example, under the simplest 1-hop interference model (also known as the node-exclusive or primary interference model), where two links interfere with each other only if they are within 1-hop distance, the throughput-optimal policy of [2] corresponds to a Maximum Weighted Matching (MWM) policy and its complexity is roughly \$O(N^{3})\$ [10], where \$N\$ is the total number of nodes in the network.
The complexity of the throughput-optimal policy of [2] for the \$K\$–hop interference model is NP-Hard [15], and hence, it is difficult to implement in practice.

context.text: Over the last few years there has been significant interest in studying the scheduling problem for multi–hop wireless networks [1]–[3][9].

First, it has been empirically observed in [3] that the centralized GMS outperforms many distributed scheduling schemes and achieves virtually the same throughput as the throughput–optimal scheduling for a variety of networking scenarios.

Second, although there have been some recently developed distributed scheduling schemes [8], [9] that can achieve the maximum achievable throughput, the study of GMS continues to remain attractive because, empirically, GMS performs better than these schemes in terms of the resultant queueing delay [3], [6].

Finally, recent studies have proposed even simpler constant-time-complexity random algorithms [3], [4], [7] that appear to approximate the performance of GMS by giving a larger weight to a link with a larger queue length.

context.text: For example, the ubiquitous IEEE 802.11 DCF (Distributed Coordination Function) wireless networks is often modeled as the 2-hop interference model [13], [14].

It has been shown only in geometric network graphs that \$\gamma^{\ast} \geq {1\over 8}\$ in the 2–hop interference model [13] and \$\gamma^{\ast}\geq{1\over 49}\$ in the \$K\$–hop interference model with \$K\geq 2\$ [15].
In [13] it has been shown that if \$d_{E}(l)\leq d\$ for all \$l\epsilon E\$, then given \$\vec{\lambda}\epsilon{1\over d}\Lambda^{\circ}\$, a Maximal Scheduling policy can stabilize the network.
However, Proposition 2 is in fact much stronger than the results in [13] and the efficiency ratio of GMS can often be shown to be larger than that of Maximal Scheduling.

[13] have shown that the efficiency ratio of Maximal Scheduling is bounded by \${1\over 8}\$ in arbitrary geometric graphs under the 2-hop model, and Sharma et al. [15] have shown that it is no smaller than \${1\over 49}\$ under any \$K\$–hop model.
In this section, we will show that GMS typically has better efficiency ratios than Maximal Scheduling studied in [13], [15].
It is well-known in the literature that the worst-case efficiency ratio of Maximal Scheduling in geometric graphs degrades when \$K\$ increases [13], [15].

context.text: Recently, Dimakis and Walrand [18] have shown that if the network topology satisfies the so-called local-pooling condition, then GMS can in fact achieves the full capacity region.
We first generalize the notion of local-pooling in [18] to the notion of local-pooling factor, which is a topological property of a graph.
The notion of local-pooling is first introduced in [18].
It was shown in [18] that, if the local-pooling factor of an arbitrary graph is 1, GMS can achieve the efficiency ratio of 1.
In [18], [19], it has been shown that GMS achieves the full capacity in tree networks under the 1-hop interference model.

context.text: The increasing demand for improving road safety and optimizing road traffic has brought a wide interest on vehicular ad hoc networks (VANETs) [1].

To the best of our knowledge, only two reported schemes, which was based on a huge number of anonymous keys (denoted as HAB in the following context) [1] and a pure group signature technique (denoted as GSB in the following context) [14], respectively, have targeted at the design of conditional privacy preservation.
One is the huge anonymous keys based (HAB) protocol [1], and the other is pure group signature technique based (GSB) protocol [14].

In [1], Raya et al. considered the secure vehicular communications in general, including anonymous message authentication and conditional privacy preservation, and HAB was developed in order to cope with these problems.

context.text: It is reasonably efficient for controlling medium access and delivers a throughput significantly higher than other non-explicit reservation MAC protocols such as Aloha, and variants of CSMA [2].
Building on the discrete Markov model of [2], we analyze the saturation throughput of 802.11 (basic mode) under both channel-oblivious and channel-aware jammer models.

The IEEE 802.11 MAC protocol is widely used and has been extensively analyzed with respect to various performance issues, including throughput, power control, fairness, as well as hidden terminal jamming problems [2], [13], [14].
Our theoretical contributions build on the framework of [2] for analyzing the saturation throughput of 802.11.
There have been several subsequent studies that refine the model of [2] or consider different traffic models, channel conditions, or performance measures (e.g., [20], [21]).

Throughout this section, we make the following assumptions for our analysis: (i) ideal channel conditions, that is, any transmission can be heard by every node in the network; thus, there are no hidden terminals or exposed terminals [2]; (ii) saturation conditions, that is, every node always has packets to send; and (iii) ideal jamming conditions, that is, a jamming signal destroys an 802.11 packet once their transmissions overlap.
Following [2], we model the exponential backoff mechanism of 802.11 MAC protocol using a bidirectional discrete-time Markov Chain.
Unlike [2], we adopt the protocol standard of a finite retransmission limit (this refinement of [2]'s model has been studied in [21]).

We follow one fundamental assumption in Bianchi's model that in steady state, the probability that a packet transmission collides with a packet transmitted by another 802.11 node is independent of the current state of the transmitting node [2].
The normalized throughput \$\Gamma\$ is expressed by (1) [2].

context.text: With the increased ease of building low-cost jammers and increased interest in studying DoS attacks, researchers have started studying the effect of adversarial jamming on 802.11 [12], [15], [16].

A recent series of studies analyzes the energy-efficiency of several jamming techniques against 802.11 [16], [17]; they demonstrate through extensive simulations that intelligent jamming by concentrating jamming signals on control packets (e.g., CTS or ACK) is significantly more energy-efficient than jammers that are oblivious to the channel.

Another difference between [16], [17] and our work is that while their performance measure of interest is the jammer energy needed to completely shut down the channel, our study considers the entire throughput range and analyzes how 802.11 throughput varies as a function of jammer rate (and, hence, energy).
The RTS/CTS exchange was designed to reserve the channel in advance and minimize the impact of collisions but obviously does not help against jamming [16], [17].

context.text: This problem is a “restless bandit” [2], an extension of the classical multi-armed bandit problem [3] in which bandits not acted upon in a given slot continue to evolve, in contrast to (static) bandits where the state of bandits that are not acted upon in a given slot is frozen.

For a relaxation of restless bandits in which the sample path constraint on the number of active bandits per slot is replaced with a constraint on the average number of active bandits per slot, Whittle [2] used a Lagrangian approach to derive a heuristic index policy, provided that the restless bandit problem under consideration satisfies a certain “Whittle indexability” property.
We use restless bandits [2] from stochastic control to study this problem.
The restless bandits problem [2] is an extension where the bandits that are not acted upon in a slot continue to evolve.
In the language of [2], this is the “active” evolution of the flow.

Whittle [2] proposed a relaxation to the restless bandits problem in which the sample path constraint on the number of active flows (bandits) per slot is replaced by a constraint on the expected number of active flows per slot.
A restless bandit problem is Whittle indexable [2] if for each bandit, the set of states for which it is optimal to stay passive increases monotonically as the reward \$-\alpha\$ increases.
Then, a restless bandit problem is said to be Whittle indexable [2] if for each bandit, \$P_{\alpha}\$ increases monotonically as the reward \$-\alpha\$ increases.
In [2], the Whittle index of a state is defined as that value of the passivity reward (Lagrange multiplier) that makes a bandit indifferent to being passive or active.
In [2], the Whittle index of a state is defined as that value of the passivity reward (Lagrange multiplier) that makes a bandit indifferent to being passive or active.

This paper applies Lagrangian relaxation techniques for the restless bandits problem [2] to derive a state-dependent index, and derive a heuristic index therefrom for the wireless real-time multicast scheduling problem.

Consequently, since \$m\$ will generally be much smaller than \$n\$, [2]'s scheme can lead to a significant reduction in monitoring overhead.
The work of [2] represents the current state-of-the-art in path performance monitoring.

However, we contend that [2]'s scheme is sub-optimal for path anomaly monitoring, and more efficient techniques that monitor fewer than \$m\$ paths can be devised for detecting path threshold violations.
In such a scenario, [2]' s approach of continuously computing delays for all paths (most of which will be normal) can lead to wastage of precious network resources.

In other words, monitoring \$m\$ linearly independent paths to calculate the delay of each and every path as is done in [2] is sufficient, but not necessary, for detecting path delay constraint violations.
Observe that since there are \$k^{2}\$ virtual links, the scheme of [2] will end up monitoring all the \$k^{2}\$ paths in \$P\$.

Case 2: In the event that the delay for one of the basic monitored paths exceeds \$k\$, our scheme monitors \$k^{2}\$ linearly independent paths and derives the individual delays for each and every link and path as in [2].
Hence, compared to [2], our efficient scheme can reduce the monitoring overhead by a factor of approximately \$k\$, for an arbitrary constant \$k\$. □.
In this paper, we propose a novel approach for detecting path threshold violations that monitors fewer paths compared to the state-of-the-art path monitoring scheme of [2].
We compare the monitoring costs of the path sets generated by our heuristic and the path monitoring scheme of [2] for an ISP topology from the Rocketfuel data set [5].

This operation resembles virtual force-based algorithms [9], [10], with a virtual expelling force between every pair of s-neighbors.
UDM differs from traditional virtual force-based algorithms [9], [10] in two key aspects.
Firstly, the virtual force in UDM stems from the PMU of events that can be far away, whereas in [9], [10], virtual force is generated by nearby nodes or obstacles.
Secondly, UDM tends to cover the c–events with the highest PMU, whereas in [9], [10], node mobility follows the composition of all virtual force exerted on the nodes.

context.text: In an experimental study in the Berkeley Wireless Research Centre [12] it was shown that the probability of detection monotonically increases as the separation between two cooperating radio increases.
Experimental study on the hard decision combining [12] concluded that the biggest cooperation gain is attained when moving from single radio to two cooperating radios.
This supports the result from the experimental study in [12] indicating that the largest increase in probability of the detection is observed when moving from single radio to two cooperating radios.

context.text: The difference between hard and soft information combining strategy has been investigated in e.g., [13] and [11].

In [13] it was concluded that soft combining clearly outperforms hard combining in terms of probability of missed opportunity, whereas, in [11] the difference between the two combining methods was reported to be small.

This can be explained by the fact that in [13] the radios are assumed to be tightly synchronized and therefore they can collectively overcome the lower bound on the SNR, below which detection is not reliable.

context.text: In [14] and [15] the performance of traditional energy detection has been analyzed.
For a conventional energy detector, the output of the integrator, which serves as decision statistic, follows the chi-square distribution [14], [15].

The probability of false alarm \$(P_{\rm f})\$ can be computed using central chi-square (or gamma) PDF with \$N\$ degrees of freedom [14]
 where \$\Gamma(.,.)\$ and \$\Gamma(.)\$ are the incomplete and complete gamma function respectively, \$N\$ is the number of degrees of freedom, \$\sigma^{2}\$ is noise variance, \$Y\$ is a decision statistic, and \$\lambda\$ is the decision threshold.

On the other hand, the probability of detection \$(P_{\rm d})\$ can be computed using noncentral chi-square PDF with \$N\$ degrees of freedom [14]
 where \$Q_{N/2} (.,.)\$ is Marcum Q-function.

The joint probability for detection \$Q_{\rm d}\$ and false alarm \$Q_{\rm f}\$ can therefore be given as [14]
 where \$n_{\rm CR}\$ denotes the number of cooperating radios and probabilities of false alarm \$P_{\rm f}\$ and detection \$P_{\rm d}\$ are calculated using (6) and (7), respectively.
